posts.name: Juergen Nieveler
posts.cooked: Would it be possible to add a dedicated settings dialogue to the Electron app to change proxy settings instead of having to set environment variables in the OS? Yes, it works, but it IS a bit cumbersome…

posts.name: Para Sympathikus
posts.cooked:
hey @Juergen_Nieveler

welcome to the signal community

first, can you talk a bit more about your use case?
why do you want to set the proxy only for signal, but not for the whole OS?

btw i guess, adding a proxy functionality is quite a lot of work, since even Chromium, on which Electron is based, uses the OS proxy settings

posts.name: Juergen Nieveler
posts.cooked:
The use case is to allow using a different proxy than for the system browser, of course

For example, for my normal work I use a transparent proxy service with filtering and SSL interception that doesn’t really play nicely with Signal. As there’s no business demand to fix it, it would be a waste of time to hunt for the issue - I have a different proxy I can use for that purpose, but I can’t use that as system proxy because some cloud services require me to access them from a specific IP (which is through the main proxy)

But really, a full-blown proxy support would not even be necessary - even just a menu where you can specify the proxy and it will set the environment variables would be nice (which BTW does seem to allow bypassing the Windows proxy settings - but I found that out by a lot of Googling, it’s not in the FAQ)
I‘m having a similar use case: at my company‘s network there‘s a proxy at home there‘s not. So currently I can use Signal desktop at only one of those networks.

posts.name: Juergen Nieveler
posts.cooked:
It was actually an error report for an older version:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop

Standalone Signal-Desktop has problems connecting through a proxy

opened 01:11AM - 01 Nov 17 UTC
janLo
Beta Don't mark stale

<!-- This is a bug report template. By following the instructions below and fill…ing out the sections with your information, you will help the developers to get all the necessary data to fix your issue. You can also preview your report before submitting it. You may remove sections that aren't relevant to your particular case. Before we begin, please note that this tracker is only for issues, not questions or comments. If you are looking for support, please see our support center instead: http://support.whispersystems.org/ or email support@whispersystems.org Let's begin with a checklist: please replace the empty checkbox [ ] below with a checked one [x] if you have searched for existing issues --> - [x] I have searched open and closed issues for duplicates ---------------------------------------- ### Bug description I've set the `http_proxy` and `https_proxy` variables on my system. Sognal-Desktop however seems to ignore them. I cannot get a connection to get the QR code. An strace says: ``` [pid 17437] 01:57:05.094195 connect(36, {sa_family=AF_INET, sin_port=htons(443), sin_addr=inet_addr("52.206.164.16")}, 16) = -1 EINPROGRESS (Operation now in progress) ``` Which is clearly not the proxy. ### Steps to reproduce - Install Signal-Desktop behind a proxy - Try to follow the steps to set it up. **Actual result:** No QR code, Server not reachable **Expected result:** QR Code, normal operation. ### Platform info **Operating System**: GNU/Linux **Browser**: Chrome **Signal version:** v1.0.34 ### Link to debug log https://gist.github.com/0bbe048ee23480d58dae34f0b07e16fe

Another use case I found mentioned in feature requests - the ability to point Signal Desktop at a TOR proxy without making your whole system use TOR (which would cause issues with Windows Update for example)

I too would like to have this feature.
I saw that even if I changed the OS wide proxy settings, signal is not honoring it !

The signal windows desktop SW can have an option for proxy in the preferences for TCP traffic.

posts.name: jad
posts.cooked:
Hi,

I’m able to get sock5 Proxy to work out with Signal, by using a special bat script :

signal.bat

set HTTP_PROXY=socks://localhost:6xxxx0
set HTTPS_PROXY=%HTTP_PROXY%
start %LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\signal-desktop\Signal.exe

It would be much more easy to just be able to set this in a “proxy” tab in settings.

Would you be so kind to manage this to happen ?

Best regards,

posts.name: censorship
posts.cooked:
@Juergen_Nieveler, @anon57865533 The reason for this not being implemented seems to be explained on this repository for using proxies with Signal on Mac OS:

Just for curiosity: Why Signal desktop App doesn’t support proxy?

According to the random talks in several proxy related open issues, it seems the Signal App uses Chromium as its fundamental platform, this proxy issue is at the Chromium layer other than the actual with-in app layer, so the developers seem to have trobuble to deal with it without touching or modding Chromium.

Apparantly most Signal developers don’t have this proxy problem, so it’s not a pirority, I guess that’s why it stays un-addressed till today. (I could be wrong it’s just from my quick grasp I’m no expert here)

@scott-signal @indutny-signal Can you guys confirm whether this is the case?

P.S. For people using Mac OS, this tool seems to be a good workaround:

GitHub

GitHub - linxucc/Proxy_Signal: Simple Apple Automator script to run Signal...

Simple Apple Automator script to run Signal with system proxy on Mac OS. - GitHub - linxucc/Proxy_Signal: Simple Apple Automator script to run Signal with system proxy on Mac OS.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked: According to the comments in [Electron] Add SOCKS proxy support · Issue #1430 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub (edit: and this post above), it appears that SOCKS proxies can also be used using the HTTP_PROXY and HTTPS_PROXY environment variables (by prefixing the URLs with socks://), so I’ve adjusted (the title of) this feature request to include SOCKS as well (for better searchability).

link_counts.title: [Electron] Add SOCKS proxy support · Issue #1430 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

posts.cooked:
FWIW, you can use command line options rather than environment variables, as detailed here (the Chromium command line flags are available in Electron apps). Not a huge difference, but easier to add to an app shortcut.

Also relevant:
Configuring a SOCKS proxy server in Chrome

link_counts.title: Configuring a SOCKS proxy server in Chrome

posts.name: Google ZZZ
posts.cooked:
Four years have passed, and it seems like the desktop version still doesn’t have proxy settings. Maybe the official team just doesn’t want to deal with it anymore.

Also, in a network environment with censorship, using a BAT proxy isn’t feasible. Only network-layer proxies like TUN can make Signal work properly, which makes it quite inconvenient for me to use.

This script allows running Signal Desktop app along with the SOCKS proxy system settings on macOS:

#!/bin/bash
export HTTPS_PROXY=socks5://127.0.0.1:8086
/Applications/Signal.app/Contents/MacOS/Signal

My version of script for macOS with SOCKS5 system proxy:

#!/bin/bash

# Extract current SOCKS proxy host and port from system settings
SOCKS_HOST=$(scutil --proxy | awk '/SOCKSProxy/ {print $3}')
SOCKS_PORT=$(scutil --proxy | awk '/SOCKSPort/ {print $3}')

if [[ -n "$SOCKS_HOST" && -n "$SOCKS_PORT" ]]; then
    export HTTPS_PROXY="socks5://$SOCKS_HOST:$SOCKS_PORT"
fi

open -a Signal

This script will always use the current proxy server and port, eliminating the need for updates if the proxy server credentials change
